channel.title: NYT > U.S. News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2020 The New York Times Company

item.title: ‘I Was a Little Scared’: Inside America’s Reopening Schools
item.description: In their first week back, students have faced altered classrooms and emergency quarantines. Here’s what they say school is like in the age of Covid-19.
item.dc:creator: Adam Wren and Dan Levin
item.media:description: Kennedy Heim, a volleyball player in Elwood, Ind., on her first day of high school. She tested positive for the coronavirus this week.

item.title: The Unique U.S. Failure to Control the Virus
item.description: Slowing the coronavirus has been especially difficult for the United States because of its tradition of prioritizing individualism and missteps by the Trump administration.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt and Lauren Leatherby
item.media:credit: Daniel Acker for The New York Times
item.media:description: A socially distant view of the Chicago River. Normal activities may be more difficult in the United States than in any other affluent country.

item.title: A Family Cries ‘Justice for Hannah.’ Will Its Rural Town Listen?
item.description: People in rural areas are killed in police shootings at about the same rate as in cities, but victims’ families and activists say they have struggled to get justice or even make themselves heard.
item.dc:creator: Jack Healy
item.media:credit: Whitney Curtis for The New York Times
item.media:description: “We’re just doing it all on our own,” said Amy Fizer, whose daughter Hannah was shot and killed by a sheriff’s deputy in Sedalia, Mo.

item.title: ‘Boxed Into a Corner,’ Sturgis Braces for Thousands to Attend Motorcycle Rally
item.description: The annual Sturgis Motorcycle Rally may attract 250,000 people even though South Dakota’s coronavirus cases have been rising.
item.dc:creator: Mark Walker
item.media:credit: Benjamin Rasmussen for The New York Times
item.media:description: Sturgis, S.D., has hosted a large motorcycle rally since 1938. Some city officials are upset that the annual festivities are starting on Friday despite a pandemic.

item.title: Arson Suspected in Denver Fire That Killed 5 From Senegal
item.description: Three adults and two children from the same family died in the early-morning house fire in Denver, the authorities said.
item.dc:creator: Neil Vigdor and Azi Paybarah
item.media:description: A homicide investigation is underway in a fatal house fire in northeast Denver, according to officials, who said that early indications pointed to foul play.

item.title: Bill Hagerty Wins Tough Tennessee Primary With Trump’s Endorsement
item.description: The fractious race to replace the outgoing Lamar Alexander signified an end to the moderate tenor that has long defined Tennessee Republicanism.
item.dc:creator: Elaina Plott
item.media:description: Bill Hagerty, who was endorsed by President Trump, won the primary to scceed the retiring Senator Lamar Alexander on Thursday.

item.title: Judge Dismisses G.O.P. Suit to End Proxy Voting in House During Pandemic
item.description: A federal judge ruled that the Constitution protected the right of the House of Representatives to make its own rules.
item.dc:creator: Luke Broadwater
item.media:credit: Stefani Reynolds for The New York Times
item.media:description: The ruling comes as Congress, which has continued to meet during the pandemic, is drawing new scrutiny over its lack of consistent virus safety protocols.

item.title: Trump, Facing Headwinds in Ohio, Talks Up Economy in Campaign Swing
item.description: The president came into 2020 considering the state a lock, but his performance in managing the pandemic and delivering on his promises from four years ago could put it in play.
item.dc:creator: Maggie Haberman
item.media:credit: Anna Moneymaker for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump on Thursday at a Whirlpool factory in Clyde, Ohio, where he delivered a winding series of remarks.

item.title: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
item.description: A resurgence of coronavirus cases in the European Union is setting off fears of a second wave.
item.dc:creator: Lara Takenaga and Jonathan Wolfe

item.title: Elizabeth Warren on Child Care in a Pandemic
item.description: The senator says child care is crucial for bringing the economy back: “Women continue to have to manage it all.”
item.dc:creator: Lisa Lerer
item.media:credit: Jordan Gale for The New York Times

item.title: Homeland Security Chief Defends Deployments in Portland
item.description: Chad F. Wolf, the agency’s acting secretary, told a Senate committee that tactical agents would remain in Oregon until the local police proved they could protect federal property.
item.dc:creator: Zolan Kanno-Youngs
item.category: Senate Committee on Homeland Security and Governmental Affairs
item.media:credit: Gabriella Demczuk for The New York Times
item.media:description: Senate Democrats questioned Chad F. Wolf, the acting secretary of homeland security, about the tactics of federal agents in Portland, Ore.

item.title: The Latest U.S. Tool to Fight Election Meddling: Text Messages
item.description: Washington sent offers to cellphones in Russia and Iran of rewards of up to $10 million for information on hackers trying to attack American voting systems.
item.dc:creator: Julian E. Barnes
item.media:credit: C.B. Schmelter/Chattanooga Times Free Press, via Associated Press
item.media:description: A polling site in Tennessee on Thursday. The Trump administration is seeking to publicize rewards for information about people trying to attack American voting systems.

item.title: At the Census Bureau, a Technical Memo Raises Alarms Over Politics
item.description: A directive orders experts to find ways to tally undocumented residents. Some fear the end result will be a skewed allotment of seats in the House of Representatives.
item.dc:creator: Michael Wines
item.media:description: A census rally outside the Supreme Court last year. Experts inside and outside the Census Bureau fear that the Trump administration wants to tailor population figures for maximum political benefit.

item.title: The Coronavirus Is New, but Your Immune System Might Still Recognize It
item.description: Some people carry immune cells called T cells that can capitalize on the virus’s resemblance to other members of its family tree.
item.dc:creator: Katherine J. Wu
item.media:description: A colorized scanning electron micrograph of a human T cell. Encounters with other coronaviruses may prime the immune system to fight the virus that causes Covid-19.

item.title: For Three Suffragists, a Monument Well Past Due
item.description: Central Park will soon unveil its first sculpture depicting nonfictional female figures. “The fact that nobody even noticed that women were missing in Central Park — what does that say about the invisibility of women?”
item.dc:creator: Alisha Haridasani Gupta
item.media:credit: Yael Malka for The New York Times
item.media:description: The sculptor Meredith Bergmann is putting the finishing touches on her suffragist sculpture, slated to be presented in Central Park on Aug. 26. It will be the park’s first — and so far only — monument honoring nonfictional women.

item.title: Why Influencers Won’t Stop Partying Anytime Soon
item.description: Creators in Los Angeles say that hosting and posting about big social gatherings is part of their job, coronavirus or no.
item.dc:creator: Taylor Lorenz
item.media:description: Tana Mongeau shared a public apology for attending a large, creator-filled birthday party at the Hype House in July.

item.title: With Old Allies Turning Against Her, Birx Presses On Against the Coronavirus
item.description: Dr. Deborah L. Birx, the White House coronavirus response coordinator, has found herself a woman without a country, denounced by Democrats and called “pathetic” by the president.
item.dc:creator: Sheryl Gay Stolberg
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.media:description: Dr. Deborah Birx’s defenders, and even her critics, say she is in a difficult spot, serving a mercurial president who has shown little regard for science.

item.title: A 4th Presidential Debate? Commission Says No to Trump
item.description: The Trump campaign had argued that the current schedule would render the debates useless to the many Americans who will vote by mail before they take place.
item.dc:creator: Matt Stevens
item.media:credit: Anna Moneymaker for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump had asked for changes to the debate schedule, a request Joe Biden’s campaign had dismissed.

item.title: ‘The Photo Does Not Look Good’: Georgia School’s Crowded Halls Go Viral
item.description: A student was suspended for five days for posting images of packed hallways at North Paulding High School, her mother said.
item.dc:creator: Giulia McDonnell Nieto del Rio
item.media:description: A crowded hallway at North Paulding High School in Dallas, Ga., on Tuesday.

item.title: Michelle Obama Says She Is Dealing With ‘Low-Grade Depression’
item.description: In her new podcast, the former first lady connected her experience with the effects of quarantine and news about civil unrest and politics.
item.dc:creator: Derrick Bryson Taylor
item.media:description: Michelle Obama said she had benefited from keeping a routine, including exercise, getting fresh air and having a regular dinner time.

item.title: Gov. Mike DeWine of Ohio Tests Positive, Then Negative, for Coronavirus
item.description: The governor said he felt confident in the results of a negative test that was taken hours after he tested positive while being screened to greet President Trump.
item.dc:creator: Sarah Mervosh
item.media:description: The initial positive test came as a surprise to Gov. Mike DeWine of Ohio, who said he had a headache but no other symptoms.

item.title: Toy Cars and Crop Tops: Can Wacky U.S.P.S. Store Merch Save the Struggling Postal Service?
item.description: Saving the American postal system, one crop top at a time.
item.dc:creator: Jackie Snow
item.media:description: The U.S. Postal Service has struggled with budget shortfalls, especially during the pandemic. The merchandise sold on usps.com helps to fill the gap.

item.title: Hurricane Forecast: ‘One of the Most Active Seasons on Record’
item.description: Scientists at NOAA updated their prediction for the 2020 hurricane season, and now expect as many as 25 named storms.
item.dc:creator: Henry Fountain
item.media:description: Hurricane Hanna over the Gulf of Mexico on July 25.

item.title: Iran Envoy Brian Hook, a ‘Survivor’ on Trump’s Team, to Quit
item.description: The exit of Brian Hook, the State Department’s special envoy for Iran, most likely rules out nuclear diplomacy with Tehran before November.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger and Michael Crowley
item.media:description: Brian Hook, the State Department’s special envoy for Iran, will be leaving his post on Thursday.

item.title: Diana Russell, Who Studied Violence Against Women, Dies at 81
item.description: She popularized the term “femicide,” to highlight the killing of women “because they are women” and to distinguish these killings from other homicides.
item.dc:creator: Katharine Q. Seelye
item.media:description: Diana E. H. Russell in 2009. Throughout her career as a scholar she studied and wrote about violence against women, including rape, incest, child abuse and battering.

item.title: New York Attorney General Sues N.R.A. and Seeks Its Closure
item.description: Letitia James seeks to dissolve the National Rifle Association, which was founded in New York, amid corruption allegations.
item.dc:creator: Danny Hakim
item.media:description: The New York attorney general, Letitia James, also sued four current or former top N.R.A. leaders, seeking tens of millions of dollars in restitution.

item.title: Even Asymptomatic People Carry the Coronavirus in High Amounts
item.description: Researchers in South Korea found that roughly 30 percent of those infected never develop symptoms yet probably spread the virus.
item.dc:creator: Apoorva Mandavilli
item.media:description: A near-empty Dongdaemun Design Plaza in Seoul in March. A South Korean team followed 193 symptomatic and 110 asymptomatic patients.

item.title: This Year’s Must-Have Back-to-School Item: Masks for Children
item.description: Crayola, Old Navy and Disney are among the brands making colorful masks for children. Child psychologists see this as a positive step toward “normalcy.”
item.dc:creator: Derrick Bryson Taylor
